code: @Manual{,   title = {riekelib: A collection of personal functions},   author = {Mark Rieke},   year = {2022},   note = {https://github.com/markjrieke/riekelib, https://markjrieke.github.io/riekelib/}, }

title: A collection of personal functions
text: Author: Mark Rieke License: MIT collection functions use regularly professional & personal projects. Formalizing development package helps speed workflows without re-define functions project. makes sense, may coalesce common functions dedicated package, can considered ever--progress testing ground. Others note intended primarily use , may well-documented error-resilient.

title: A collection of personal functions
text: ’d like use, package can installed devtools package:

title: A collection of personal functions
text: currently function groups package: stats_extensions.R contains functions provide interface stats package; namely, adding confidence intervals common distributions. bound_transforms.R contains functions rescale values bound scale unbounded scale, vice-versa. qualtrics_extensions.R contains functions build upon qualtRics package, unlikely accepted PR. tidyverse_extensions.R contains functions aggregate common data transformation steps single function calls. nps.R contains functions working Net Promoter Score (NPS) data.

what: Sort a vector by alphabetic or numeric order — arrange_vector

text: Sort vector alphabetic numeric order

title: Sort a vector by alphabetic or numeric order — arrange_vector
Sort a vector by alphabetic or numeric order — arrange_vector
text: x vector sorted desc logical; set true, return vector sorted descending order

title: Sort a vector by alphabetic or numeric order — arrange_vector
code: # create a character vector myvec <- c("dog", "cat", "bird")  # arrange vector by character arrange_vector(myvec) #> [1] "bird" "cat"  "dog"   # can also arrange in reverse order arrange_vector(myvec, desc = TRUE) #> [1] "dog"  "cat"  "bird"

what: Functions for the Dirichlet Distribution — dirichlet

text: Functions compute density generate random deviates Dirichlet distribution

title: Functions for the Dirichlet Distribution — dirichlet
Functions for the Dirichlet Distribution — dirichlet
text: x vector containing single random deviate matrix containing one random deviate per row. alpha Vector (ddirichlet) matrix containing shape parameters. n Number random vectors generate.

title: Functions for the Dirichlet Distribution — dirichlet
text: ddirichlet returns vector containing Dirichlet density corresponding rows x. rdirichlet returns matrix n rows, containing single Dirichlet random deviate.

title: Functions for the Dirichlet Distribution — dirichlet
text: Dirichlet distribution multidimensional generalization beta distribution.  canonical Bayesian distribution parameter estimates multinomial distribution.

title: Functions for the Dirichlet Distribution — dirichlet
text: ddirichlet(): Dirichlet distribution function. rdirichlet(): Generate dirichlet random deviates.

title: Functions for the Dirichlet Distribution — dirichlet
text: Code original posted Ben Bolker R-News Fri Dec 15 2000. See https://stat.ethz.ch/pipermail/r-help/2000-December/009561.html.  Ben attributed code Ian Wilson .wilson@maths.abdn.ac.uk. Subsequent modifications Gregory R. Warnes greg@warnes.net.

what: Fetch a list of Qualtrics surveys by name via the Qualtrics API — fetch_surveys

title: Fetch a list of Qualtrics surveys by name via the Qualtrics API — fetch_surveys
Fetch a list of Qualtrics surveys by name via the Qualtrics API — fetch_surveys
text: survey_names vector survey names appear Qualtrics UI. ... Additional arguments passed qualtRics::fetch_survey().

title: Fetch a list of Qualtrics surveys by name via the Qualtrics API — fetch_surveys
text: single value supplied survey_names: tibble survey responses qualtRics::fetch_survey(). multiple survey_names, tibble colums survey_name, survey_id, responses. responses contains responses survey returned qualtRics::fetch_survey().

title: Fetch a list of Qualtrics surveys by name via the Qualtrics API — fetch_surveys
code: if (FALSE) { # fetch a single survey by name my_survey <- fetch_surveys("my cool survey")  # fetch multiple surveys by name my_surveys <- fetch_surveys(c("my cool survey", "my lame survey")) }

what: Call ggsave with default parameters — ggquicksave
title: Call ggsave with default parameters — ggquicksave
text: Call ggsave default parameters

title: Call ggsave with default parameters — ggquicksave
code: ggquicksave(   filename,   plot = ggplot2::last_plot(),   width = 9,   height = 6,   units = "in",   dpi = 500,   device = grDevices::png,   ... )

title: Call ggsave with default parameters — ggquicksave
text: filename File name create disk. plot Plot save, defaults last plot displayed. width, height, units Plot size units ("", "cm", "mm", "px"). dpi Plot resolution. Also accepts string input: "retina" (320), "print" (300), "screen" (72). device Device format (e.g., one "eps", "ps", "tex", "pdf", "jpeg", "tiff", "png", "bmp", "svg", "wmf") ... arguments passed ggplot2::ggsave().

title: Call ggsave with default parameters — ggquicksave
code: if (FALSE) { library(ggplot2) ggplot(mtcars, aes(mpg, wt)) +   geom_point()  ggquicksave("mtcars.png") }

what: Transform a between bound and unbounded scales. — logit
title: Transform a between bound and unbounded scales. — logit
text: Transform bound unbounded scales.

title: Transform a between bound and unbounded scales. — logit
code: logit(x, lower_bound = 0, upper_bound = 1, base = exp(1))  expit(x, lower_bound = 0, upper_bound = 1, base = exp(1))

title: Transform a between bound and unbounded scales. — logit
text: x Value rescaled. lower_bound Lower bound x; defaults 0. upper_bound Upper bound x; defaults 1. base Base used log-transform, defaults exp(1) = e

title: Transform a between bound and unbounded scales. — logit
text: logit() transform value bound scale unbound scale, expit() performs reverse transformation. Values lower/upper bounds correspond -Inf/Inf unbounded scale. Uses natural base, e, default, bases can passed parameter base.

title: Transform a between bound and unbounded scales. — logit

title: Return the percentage each value or combination of values appear in a tibble or dataframe — percent
Return the percentage each value or combination of values appear in a tibble or dataframe — percent
text: .data tibble dataframe ... parameters pass dplyr::count() .keep_n logical; keep remove n col created dplyr::count(). Defaults FALSE.

title: Return the percentage each value or combination of values appear in a tibble or dataframe — percent
code: # return a tibble of the percentage of gear type in the `mtcars` dataset percent(mtcars, gear) #>   gear     pct #> 1    3 0.46875 #> 2    4 0.37500 #> 3    5 0.15625

title: Net Promoter Score (NPS) — rnps
text: rnps() generates n random possible net promoter scores based sample promoter, passive, detractor responses. qnps() simulates sample NPS scores, produces sample quantiles corresponding given probabilities.

title: Net Promoter Score (NPS) — rnps
code: rnps(n, promoters, passives, detractors)  qnps(   p,   promoters,   passives,   detractors,   sims = 10000,   na.rm = FALSE,   names = FALSE,   ... )

title: Net Promoter Score (NPS) — rnps
text: n number observations generate. promoters, passives, detractors counts promoters, passives, detractors p vector quantiles. sims number simulated NPS scores generate use sample quantile calculation. na.rm logical; true, NA NaNs removed quantiles computed. names logical; true, result names attribute. Set FALSE speedup many probs. ... additional params pass stats::quantile()

title: Net Promoter Score (NPS) — rnps
